results.title: The Garden
results.creator_credit: Derek Jarman, James MacKay, Basilisk Productions, Screen Arts and Channel 4
results.brief_description: The Garden is rich with metaphor. The Garden of Eden and the Garden of Gethsemane. In the garden is visible the whole sensual cycle of life and death. We watch the Passion enacted by two male lovers, filmed in the garden Jarman himself created and retreated within to prepare for his own battle with mortality. In “The Garden” the spirit and the flesh, sin and redemption, are united. Like Pasolini, Jarman eschews classic narrative for the pleasures of a cinema of poetry and seeks a spirituality based on eros rather than repression. A difficult, maddening, wondrous film. With the glorious Tilda Swinton.

results.title: The Garbage pail kids
results.creator_credit: Rodney Amateau and Topps Chewing Gum Production
results.brief_description: The Garbage pail kids was a novelty item, bubblegum card created in the late 1980s. The characters appearing on each card were designed to appeal to kids and promoted ‘gross-out’ subjects such as snot and farts. Made hastily to capitalise on the promotion’s success, the film is a comic fantasy in which the bubblegum characters of Valerie Vomit, Windy Winston, Foul Phil and Ali Gator come to life. Dodger (MacKenzie Astin) is the young friend of retired magician, antique store owner and man of mystery, Captain Manzini (Anthony Newley). When Dodger is bullied by a bunch of street villains he turns to The Garbage Pail Kids for help after he unwittingly releases them from their garbage pail (jail). Havoc and adventure results with a plethora of gross-out adventures. Although the film was intended for children some of the themes are more suited for teenagers. Film contains adult language, adult situations, mild violence and a “State home for the ugly”.

results.title: The Gap
results.brief_description: From dawn one morning until dawn the next day, a man in deep despair tries to end his life by jumping off “The Gap”, a cliff at the mouth of the Sydney Harbour. The entrance is one of mixed and dichotomous meanings, as it is the gateway to a majestic city as well as a place of unutterable sadness where people go to die. Two cops are sent to talk him down. The man outdoes them in his dignity and his courage.

results.title: The Games: the millennium bug
results.creator_credit: Bruce Permezel, Denise Eriksen, ABC-TV (Australia) and Beyond Productions
results.brief_description: The first four episodes from the ABC comedy documentary series, The Games. Episode 1: John and Gina meet the Sydney spindoctors while Bryan finds the unbelievable - a willing sponsor with millions to spend. Episode 2: John confronts the threat of the Millenium Bug, and finds a worldwide audience for The Games on the Net. Episode 3: Our team goes bush to a conference centre to workshop the problems they face at The Games. Episode 4: The consultants are out to get Bryan but our team proves that home-grown expertise can beat corporate slickness any day. Written by John Clarke and Ross Stevenson.

results.title: The Games: sharing the blame
results.creator_credit: Bruce Permezel, Finishing Touches Productions and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: This video contains four episodes from series two of the outstanding ABC series “The Games”, a satirical (but often painfully close to the truth) mock documentary of SOCOG and their preparations for the Sydney 2000 Olympic Games. The episodes included cover the following issues: an in-depth look at the lives of some of the main players behind the scenes of the Committee; what happens when everything is running according to schedule; the life story of one (or perhaps two) of the many thousands of international guests who will come to see the Games; the use of inquiries to ensure that the accidental misuse of process by Committee members is quickly exposed and rectified.

results.title: The Games
results.creator_credit: Bruce Permezel, Ross Stevenson, John Clarke, ABC-TV (Australia) and Beyond Productions
results.brief_description: A mock documentary about how not to prepare for the Sydney Olympics, or any Olympics for that matter. This tape includes four episodes from the popular television satire. Incidents arising from the episodes include; accuracy, in particular the construction of the 100 metre track; the importance of flying with approved airlines and what happens when two international figures arrive on a non official airline; John appears on television defending Australia’s position on the environment while Bryan and Gina hear a proposal from rural Australia regarding the opening ceremony; there are moves to bring in an infallible drug test to the Olympics, but will it bring more harm than good? Cast includes John Clarke, Gina Riley and Bryan Dawe.

results.title: The Game is up!
results.creator_credit: John Tutty, Meg Labrum and National Film and Sound Archive of Australia
results.brief_description: The National Film and Sound Archive has drawn on its unique film collection in a selection of vintage newsreels, home movies, advertisements and feature film footage looking at women’s contribution to Australia’s sporting culture. The video is accompanied by an excellent teacher resource guide. Presented in chronological order some of the highlights include Annette Kellerman’s underwater ballet in 1914, Vera James in the classic film of 1921, ‘A Girl of the bush’, The Australian Women’s Cricket team of 1937 and of course the golden girls of the Melbourne Olympics of 1956.

results.title: The Game
results.creator_credit: Les Clark, Ken Peterson and Walt Disney Educational Materials
results.brief_description: An animated film made for children, which poses the questions - how come some kids never play by the rules? Why do they always wan special treatment? Should the rules be changed? Various alternatives are offered for each problem but the real answers will be those which arise from group discussions.

results.title: The Game
results.creator_credit: George Kaczender, John Kemeny and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: This is the boy-meets-girl game, but played without rules and at a time when the boy must prove himself in the chase. It is about the much-discussed sexual behavior of teenagers and shows that often the game starts with a challenge to his masculine ego from the boy’s peer group. Few adults are seen or heard from, nor does the film take sides in this game. A dramatisation.

results.brief_description: An animated film which deals with the problem of how to cope with playing by the rules and with those sho do not abide by the rules. Suitable for middle and upper primary and lower secondary levels.
